Output: The metric chosen for SCC detection at the cancer margin in excised tissue specimens from 102 patients is the area under the curve (AUC) of the receiver-operator characteristic (ROC). instruction: Can label-free, reflectance-based hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and autofluorescence imaging methods be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately detecting the cancer margin in excised tissue specimens from patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)?
Output: Yes, label-free, reflectance-based hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and autofluorescence imaging methods can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately detecting the cancer margin in excised tissue specimens from patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). According to the study, HSI classified conventional SCC with an AUC of 0.82 up to 3 mm from the cancer margin, which was more accurate than proflavin dye and autofluorescence. Intra-patient autofluorescence imaging also detected human papilloma virus positive (HPV+) SCC with an AUC of 0.99 at 3 mm and had greater accuracy than proflavin dye. The inter-patient results showed that reflectance-based HSI and autofluorescence imaging outperformed proflavin dye and standard red, green, and blue (RGB) images. Additionally, in new patients, HSI detected conventional SCC in the larynx, oropharynx, and nasal cavity with AUC scores ranging from 0.85 to 0.95, and autofluorescence imaging detected HPV+ SCC in tonsillar tissue with a 0.91 AUC score.
